title: Verify any unused email address

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** 
Verify any unused email address in twitter account

**Description:** 
After signing up on twitter it's recommended for a user to verify his/her email address to avoid spam and impersonation, I was able to verify the email without having access to the email itself.

## Steps To Reproduce:
It's a bit complex I'll write and make a video
Requirments:
1.Telerik Fiddler (setuped for using https)
2.A Twitter account that you have access to it's Email address

Steps:
1. Open Fiddler then click `file` and enable `capture traffic` then go to https://twitter.com/signup
2. Stop capturing once this URL is captured https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup
3. In fiddler click on the url and in the response click raw and copy all the response then paste and save them in a new file make sure to save them in UTF-8 encoding (ansi won't work)
4. In fiddler click on Autoresponder and click "Add rule" in "rule editor" first field enter `EXACT:https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup` in second field open dropdown menu and click `find a file` and select the file that you saved and click `save` and finally check 'Enable rules' then click `file` > `Capture traffic`
5. go to https://twitter.com/login then login with your twitter account
6. then go to https://twitter.com/signup enter name and `Use email instead` then enter any email address to verify then click next then click `sign up`
7. login to your email address attached to your Twitter account that you logged in with you will find that the verification code is sent to you copy it and enter it to verify the other email that you signed up with then enter a password and continue and now you got an email verified twitter account 

## Supporting Material/References:
I uploaded a video

## Impact

1) Authenticating attackers to users accounts with Twitter oauth in third parties applications
suppose that a website (www.example.com) have 2 methods for login 
- Login with email address
- Login with Twitter account (in case that the website requires user email to authenticate users)
If the user is using an email address that is not signed up on twitter, an attacker is able to signup and verify the email address then login with twitter and access all victim data in third parties applications 
2) Impersonate a user by verifying his/her email address on a twitter account and making crimes using this account.
3) spam, creating a huge amount of verified twitter accounts and spam
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
Verify any unused email address in twitter account

Description:
After signing up on twitter it's recommended for a user to verify his/her email address to avoid spam and impersonation, I was able to verify the email without having access to the email itself.

Steps To Reproduce:

It's a bit complex I'll write and make a video
Requirments:
1.Telerik Fiddler (setuped for using https)
2.A Twitter account that you have access to it's Email address

Steps:

  1. Open Fiddler then click file and enable capture traffic then go to https://twitter.com/signup
  2. Stop capturing once this URL is captured https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup
  3. In fiddler click on the url and in the response click raw and copy all the response then paste and save them in a new file make sure to save them in UTF-8 encoding (ansi won't work)
  4. In fiddler click on Autoresponder and click "Add rule" in "rule editor" first field enter EXACT:https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup in second field open dropdown menu and click find a file and select the file that you saved and click save and finally check 'Enable rules' then click file > Capture traffic
  5. go to https://twitter.com/login then login with your twitter account
  6. then go to https://twitter.com/signup enter name and Use email instead then enter any email address to verify then click next then click sign up
  7. login to your email address attached to your Twitter account that you logged in with you will find that the verification code is sent to you copy it and enter it to verify the other email that you signed up with then enter a password and continue and now you got an email verified twitter account

Supporting Material/References:

I uploaded a video

Impact

1) Authenticating attackers to users accounts with Twitter oauth in third parties applications
suppose that a website (www.example.com) have 2 methods for login

  • Login with email address
  • Login with Twitter account (in case that the website requires user email to authenticate users) If the user is using an email address that is not signed up on twitter, an attacker is able to signup and verify the email address then login with twitter and access all victim data in third parties applications 2) Impersonate a user by verifying his/her email address on a twitter account and making crimes using this account. 3) spam, creating a huge amount of verified twitter accounts and spam

activities.message: I reread my report and I'm not sure if it was clear enough so feel free to ask

activities.message:
Thank you for your report @seifelsallamy.

We are having difficulty reproducing the issue you are seeing here. In our tests, the request to `api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json` was not made until Step 3 of the signup process, on the "We sent you a code" screen. We also did not see the query parameter ,`flow_name=signup` in that URL, at any point during our signup flow. Can you confirm if the request to that endpoint was made in the same step of your signup flow? In addition, from your video, we noticed several parameters from your request to `api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup`, which did not show up in our request. Some examples of parameters we didn't see on our end are:

> password_hint
> progress_indication
> subtask_navigation_context
> subtask_data_reference
> is_destructive
> suppress_client_events
> invalid_birthday_link

For reference, the body of our request to the same endpoint contained the following:

>
{"flow_token":"[flowtoken]","subtask_inputs":[{"subtask_id":"GenerateTemporaryPassword","fetch_temporary_password":{"password":"[password]","link":"next_link"}},{"subtask_id":"Signup","sign_up":{"email":"[email]","js_instrumentation":{"response":"{\"rf\":{\"[rf]\":-2,\"[-2]\":-86,\"[-86]\":-2,\"[30]\":30},\"s\":\"[s\]"}"},"link":"next_link","name":"[name]","personalization_settings":{"allow_cookie_use":true,"allow_device_personalization":true,"allow_partnerships":true,"allow_ads_personalization":true}}},{"subtask_id":"SignupReview","sign_up_review":{"link":"signup_with_email_next_link"}},{"subtask_id":"EmailVerification","email_verification":{"code":"[code]","email":"[email]","link":"next_link"}}]}



Could you provide a sample request body, such as the one from your video? Any additional information you could provide would help us investigate your report.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

{F487583}
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report @seifelsallamy.

We are having difficulty reproducing the issue you are seeing here. In our tests, the request to api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json was not made until Step 3 of the signup process, on the "We sent you a code" screen. We also did not see the query parameter ,flow_name=signup in that URL, at any point during our signup flow. Can you confirm if the request to that endpoint was made in the same step of your signup flow? In addition, from your video, we noticed several parameters from your request to api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup, which did not show up in our request. Some examples of parameters we didn't see on our end are:

password_hint
progress_indication
subtask_navigation_context
subtask_data_reference
is_destructive
suppress_client_events
invalid_birthday_link

For reference, the body of our request to the same endpoint contained the following:

{"flow_token":"[flowtoken]","subtask_inputs":[{"subtask_id":"GenerateTemporaryPassword","fetch_temporary_password":{"password":"[password]","link":"next_link"}},{"subtask_id":"Signup","sign_up":{"email":"[email]","js_instrumentation":{"response":"{\"rf\":{\"[rf]\":-2,\"[-2]\":-86,\"[-86]\":-2,\"[30]\":30},\"s\":\"[s]"}"},"link":"next_link","name":"[name]","personalization_settings":{"allow_cookie_use":true,"allow_device_personalization":true,"allow_partnerships":true,"allow_ads_personalization":true}}},{"subtask_id":"SignupReview","sign_up_review":{"link":"signup_with_email_next_link"}},{"subtask_id":"EmailVerification","email_verification":{"code":"[code]","email":"[email]","link":"next_link"}}]}

Could you provide a sample request body, such as the one from your video? Any additional information you could provide would help us investigate your report.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
I have no idea why you can't see this url, anyway that's the response I receive F487645 ,
in the POC steps you can escape steps 1,2,3 and start from step 4 using the response file I uploaded
But there will be a problem the AutoResponder is responding the response I uploaded instead of the server's response to the request to `https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup` endpoint
which is not shown to you so the autoresponder will respond to nothing :/ 
I tried using burp + Firefox to capture `https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup` and I succeeded 
so the problem isn't in the browser or the proxy server maybe the ip address I'm from Egypt you may try an Egyptian ip
also you may try the mobile site https://mobile.twitter.com/signup it may work

activities.message:
I got it!
You don't need to sign up to find this url `https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup`
but all you have to do is to visit https://twitter.com/signup and the browser will automatically call  `https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup` 
So the reason that you didn't got this url  `https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup` is most likely cache.
In Firefox I couldn't get to this url after the first time I visited it, that's because it's cached 
clean the cache start capturing traffic then go to https://twitter.com/signup or use chrome instead

clean the cache start capturing traffic then go to https://twitter.com/signup or use chrome instead

activities.message:
Thank you for the additional details @seifelsallamy.

While we were able to see the request from `api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup` when we cleared our cache in Firefox, we are still experiencing difficulty in reproducing the behavior in your report. When we performed the following steps, we were unable to sign up with the fake email.

1. Access https://twitter.com/signup, and intercept the response from `api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup`.
2. Select "Use email instead", enter a real email address that we have access to, and continue through the Sign Up flow.
3. Enter the Verification code sent to our email (ex: 123456), and complete the Sign Up process.
4. Log out of the new Twitter account, and clear our browser's cache.
5. Revisit https://twitter.com/signup, and edit the response from `api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup`, to match that of the captured response from step 1.
6. Select "Use email instead", and enter a *fake* email address, and continue through the Sign Up Flow.

When we followed these steps, we did **not** receive a new Verification Code to our real email after completing step 6. We also tried entering the old verification code from the real email (ex: 123456), and received an error.

In your original steps, you appear to access the Sign Up page, while still logged in, is this correct? In our steps, we were presented with an error when attempting to access https://twitter.com/signup while still logged in. 

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

██████████

When we performed the following steps, we were unable to sign up with the fake email.

  1. Access https://twitter.com/signup, and intercept the response from api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup.
  2. Select "Use email instead", enter a real email address that we have access to, and continue through the Sign Up flow.
  3. Enter the Verification code sent to our email (ex: 123456), and complete the Sign Up process.
  4. Log out of the new Twitter account, and clear our browser's cache.
  5. Revisit https://twitter.com/signup, and edit the response from api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup, to match that of the captured response from step 1.
  6. Select "Use email instead", and enter a fake email address, and continue through the Sign Up Flow.

When we followed these steps, we did not receive a new Verification Code to our real email after completing step 6. We also tried entering the old verification code from the real email (ex: 123456), and received an error.

In your original steps, you appear to access the Sign Up page, while still logged in, is this correct? In our steps, we were presented with an error when attempting to access https://twitter.com/signup while still logged in.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

██████████

activities.message: All your steps are right except that you have to be logged in with you real account while signing up your fake account.
activities.markdown_message: All your steps are right except that you have to be logged in with you real account while signing up your fake account.

Thank you for your response @seifelsallamy.

When we attempted to access the Sign Up page at https://twitter.com/signup while logged in, we received an error in the response from api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup, and we were unable to access the page. In our tests, this error occurred in both Chrome and Firefox. Can you clarify how you were able to access the Sign Up page while logged in, without experiencing this error? Any additional information you can provide will help us investigate your report.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
That's exactly why you are recording the response of ```https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup``` while you're logged out (to bypass this error)

POC Steps:
1) sign up for the real account and logout
2) while you're logged out go to signup page and capture ```https://api.twitter.com/1.1/onboarding/task.json?flow_name=signup``` response
3) login with real account
4) go to signup page and replay with the response you captured in step 2 (to bypass this error) 
5) signup with the fake account then go to the email of the real account you will find the verification code of the fake account

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
